questions.text: An intern was checking the blood pressure of patients coming to the medicine OPD. However, the consultant told the intern that he was using a large cuff for the measurement of Bp and his readings were wrong. How does a large cuff affect the BP recordings?

options.label: C
options.text: It affects only the diastolic blood pressure

options.label: D
options.text: Is the same with different cuff sizes

questions.explanation:
Solution:

It underestimates the BP

Highyeild:

Measuring Blood Pressure:- 1. Cuff width should be > 80% of the arm circumference. 2. Systolic pressure. The appearance of sustained repetitive tapping sound (Korotkoff) 3. Diastolic pressure usually causes the disappearance of sounds (Korotkoff V ) 4. In some individuals (eg. pregnant women and AR) sounds are present until the zero point. 5. In this case the muffing of sounds (Korotkoff IV ) should be used. 6. BP measured in the arms is usually more than intraarterial pressure , specially in o bese people , people with muscular bodies, and in old people. 7. A small BP cuff overestimates the BP and a large BP cuff underestimates the BP 8. Salient gap (auscultatory gap):- a. Auscultatory gap is a period of diminished or absent Korotkoff sounds during the manual measurement of blood pressure. b. To correct for an auscultatory gap the radial pulse should be monitored by palpation.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B- A small BP cuff overestimates the BP Option C- both systolic and diastolic pressures are affected Option D- False. So, Options B, C, and D are not the correct options.

questions.text: A 78-year-old male with hypertension (Controlled on anti-hypertensive drugs) presents with new onset of mild left hemiparesis and the finding of atrial fibrillation. Which of the following must be done?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Both B and C This patient has CHADS2 score of 5 (stroke =2 points, age =2 points and 1 point for hypertension) Aspirin alone might be sufficient for a stroke patient without the complicating factor of atrial fibrillation . However, in patients with atrial fibrillation, in whom the risk of stroke approaches 30%, therapeutic anticoagulation with warfarin reduces the incidence of future stroke to a greater extent than the use of aspirin. This particular patient may be a candidate for medical or electrical cardioversion, which requires pretreatment with warfarin for 3 weeks (if the atrial fibrillation has been present for over 48 h or is of unknown onset).

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A - Alternatively, a transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) could be performed to exclude the presence of left atrial thrombus, followed by cardioversion and then maintenance warfarin anticoagulation for 3-4 weeks.

questions.text: Which of the following is TRUE about pulses paradoxus?

options.label: A
options.text: Rise in systolic pressure >10 mmHg during inspiration

options.label: B
options.text: Rise in systolic pressure >10 mmHg during expiration

options.label: C
options.text: fall in systolic pressure >10 mmHg during inspiration

options.label: D
options.text: fall in systolic pressure >10 mmHg during expiration

questions.correct_answer: C. fall in systolic pressure >10 mmHg during inspiration
questions.explanation:
Solution:

fall in systolic pressure >10 mmHg during inspiration Pulsus paradoxus refers to an exaggerated fall in systolic pressure >10 mmHg with inspiration that is seen in patients with pericardial tamponade but also is described in those with massive pulmonary embolism, hemorrhagic shock, severe obstructive lung disease, and tension pneumothorax. Pulsus paradoxus can be observed in cardiac tamponade and in conditions where intrathoracic pressure swings are exaggerated or the right ventricle is distended, such as severe acute asthma or exacerbations of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A: Pulsus paradoxus is exaggerated fall NOT rise. Option: B: In normal pulse, SBP rises during expiration. Option: D: During Inspiration NOT expiration.

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: Fall in systolic pressure >20 mmHg and diastolic pressure >10 mmHg

questions.correct_answer: C. Fall in systolic pressure >20 mmHg or in diastolic pressure >10 mmHg
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Fall in systolic pressure >20 mmHg or in diastolic pressure >10 mmHg Orthostatic hypotension is defined by a fall in systolic pressure >20 mmHg or in diastolic pressure >10 mmHg in response to the assumption of the upright posture from a supine position within 3 min. There may also be a lack of compensatory tachycardia, an abnormal response that suggests autonomic insufficiency, as seen in patients with diabetes or Parkinson’s disease. Orthostatic hypotension is a common cause of postural lightheadedness/syncope and should be assessed routinely in patients for whom this diagnosis might pertain. It can be exacerbated by advanced age, dehydration, certain medications, food, deconditioning, and ambient temperature/humidity.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A, B: SBP>20 or DBP >10. Option: D: Either SBP or DBP can be taken. BOTH are NOT needed to be present.

questions.text: To define white coat hypertension, what BP findings must be at least in the absence of any evidence of target organ damage?

options.label: A
options.text: One clinic-based measurement >140/90 mmHg and one non-clinic-based measurement <140/90 mmHg

options.label: B
options.text: Two separate clinic-based measurements >140/90 mmHg and two non-clinic-based measurements < 140/90 mmHg

options.label: C
options.text: Two separate clinic-based measurements >140/90 mmHg and one non-clinic- based measurement < 140/90 mmHg

options.label: D
options.text: Three separate clinic-based measurements >140/90 mmHg and two non-clinic-based measurements < 140/90 mmHg

questions.correct_answer: D. Three separate clinic-based measurements >140/90 mmHg and two non-clinic-based measurements < 140/90 mmHg
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Three separate clinic-based measurements >140/90 mmHg and two non-clinic-based measurements < 140/90 mmHg “White coat hypertension” is defined by at least three separate clinic-based measurements >140/90 mmHg and at least two non-clinic-based measurements < 140/90 mmHg in the absence of any evidence of target organ damage. Individuals with white coat hypertension may not benefit from drug therapy, although they may be more likely to develop sustained hypertension over time

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A, B, D: At least three separate clinic-based and two non-clinic-based measurements are required.

questions.text: Which is the most common cause of death in hypertensive patients?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Heart disease Heart disease is the most common cause of death in hypertensive patients. Hypertensive heart disease is the result of structural and functional adaptations leading to left ventricular hypertrophy, CHF, atherosclerotic coronary artery disease and microvascular disease, and cardiac arrhythmias, including atrial fibrillation.

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A: Stroke is the second most frequent cause of death in the world. Elevated blood pressure is the strongest risk factor for stroke. Option: D: In patients with the clinical syndrome of malignant hypertension, encephalopathy is related to the failure of autoregulation of cerebral blood flow at the upper-pressure limit, resulting in vasodilation and hyperperfusion.
